content.text: Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of preventable blindness worldwide. It is caused by repeated infections with specific serotypes (A, B, Ba, C) of Chlamydia trachomatis. The disease thrives in conditions of poverty, poor sanitation, and inadequate water supply. Chronic, repeated infections lead to a scarring process in the conjunctiva, causing inwardly turned eyelashes (trichiasis) that abrade the cornea, leading to corneal opacity and blindness.

rows: Presence of five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.
Inflammatory thickening of the upper tarsal conjunctiva that obscures more than half of the normal deep tarsal vessels.
Presence of easily visible scars in the tarsal conjunctiva.
At least one eyelash rubs on the eyeball.
Easily visible corneal opacity over the pupil.

components.description: Surgical correction for trichiasis (TT) to prevent corneal damage.
Antibiotic treatment for active infection (TF and/or TI).
Promoting personal hygiene, particularly face washing in children, to reduce transmission.
Improving access to clean water and sanitation to reduce the reservoir of infection.

regimenData.notes: Azithromycin is preferred for mass drug administration (MDA) campaigns due to its single-dose convenience. Tetracycline ointment is an alternative for individual cases.
